claim: People smoke more on average in the United States than in Russia.

supporting.text: According to the World Health Organization, the United States has a higher adult smoking prevalence rate than Russia.

attacks.text: According to the World Health Organization, the United States has a higher adult smoking prevalence rate than Russia.
The WHO data may not account for differences in data collection methodologies between the two countries, potentially skewing the comparison.
The WHO standardizes data collection protocols globally to ensure comparability across countries.
Cultural differences in self-reporting smoking habits could lead to underreporting in Russia compared to the US.
Studies using biochemical verification (e.g., cotinine tests) confirm that self-reported smoking rates in Russia are generally accurate.
The claim ignores recent trends, as Russia has implemented stricter anti-smoking laws in the past decade, reducing smoking rates.
The WHO data cited is from the most recent year available and already reflects post-policy changes in both countries.

supporting.text: Per capita cigarette consumption data from the CDC and Russian health agencies shows higher average smoking rates in the U.S. compared to Russia.

attacks.text: Per capita cigarette consumption data from the CDC and Russian health agencies shows higher average smoking rates in the U.S. compared to Russia.
The data may not account for differences in reporting methodologies between the CDC and Russian health agencies, potentially skewing the comparison.
Both the CDC and Russian health agencies follow standardized international reporting guidelines, ensuring methodological consistency.
The per capita data does not consider the black market or informal cigarette sales, which are more prevalent in Russia and could mean actual smoking rates are higher there.
Studies on illicit tobacco trade suggest the black market share in Russia, while significant, is not large enough to reverse the per capita consumption gap with the U.S.

supporting.text: U.S. tobacco industry reports indicate greater annual cigarette sales volumes per capita than official Russian sales figures.

attacks.text: U.S. tobacco industry reports indicate greater annual cigarette sales volumes per capita than official Russian sales figures.
Official Russian sales figures may underreport actual consumption due to unregulated or black-market tobacco sales.
Studies on Russian tobacco consumption patterns suggest black-market sales are a minor fraction of total consumption.
Per capita sales figures do not account for differences in smoking frequency or intensity between populations.
Surveys indicate U.S. smokers consume more cigarettes per day on average than Russian smokers.

supporting.text: National health surveys in both countries consistently report higher percentages of daily smokers among U.S. adults compared to Russian adults.

attacks.text: National health surveys in both countries consistently report higher percentages of daily smokers among U.S. adults compared to Russian adults.
Russian health surveys may underreport smoking rates due to cultural stigma or lack of transparency in data collection.
Independent international health organizations validate Russian smoking data through cross-referencing with other metrics, reducing underreporting concerns.
The definition of 'daily smoker' may differ between the U.S. and Russian surveys, leading to incomparable percentages.
Both countries adhere to WHO standards for defining 'daily smoker,' ensuring methodological consistency.

supporting.text: The U.S. has weaker tobacco control policies than Russia's comprehensive anti-smoking laws, contributing to higher smoking rates.

attacks.text: The U.S. has weaker tobacco control policies than Russia's comprehensive anti-smoking laws, contributing to higher smoking rates.
Despite weaker policies, U.S. smoking rates have declined significantly over the past two decades due to cultural shifts and public health campaigns.
Russia's smoking rates remain higher than the U.S. due to lax enforcement of anti-smoking laws and high tobacco industry influence.
Smoking prevalence in Russia is underreported due to informal markets and non-compliance with surveys, making direct comparisons unreliable.
International health organizations like WHO confirm Russia's higher smoking rates despite underreporting, using standardized methodologies.

supporting.text: Comparative studies of nicotine dependence show higher average cigarette consumption per smoker in the U.S. than in Russia.

attacks.text: Comparative studies of nicotine dependence show higher average cigarette consumption per smoker in the U.S. than in Russia.
Russian smokers may underreport consumption due to cultural stigma or lack of formal surveys in rural areas.
WHO and Global Adult Tobacco Survey (GATS) data standardize reporting methods across countries, minimizing underreporting bias.
U.S. studies disproportionately sample heavy smokers in treatment programs, skewing averages upward.
National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) uses representative sampling of all U.S. adults, not just clinical populations.
Russian smokers compensate with higher tar cigarettes or non-cigarette tobacco, making per-unit comparisons misleading.
